thread.title: Political analogy does not go down well with Irish rugby fans
thread.title_full: Political analogy does not go down well with Irish rugby fans - Telegraph

author: James Stafford
title: Political analogy does not go down well with Irish rugby fans
text: Major sporting matches are always jumped on by marketers and political figures to try and hijack a little of the media spotlight for themselves. Some pull it off better than others. Just before Ireland squared up with Argentina in their quarter-final, Irish political party Fine Gael decided to jump in with a rather odd rugby/political analogy. FACT: If the Rugby World Cup was based on economic growth, Ireland would win hands down #IREvARG #ShoulderToShoulder pic.twitter.com/3j9YabKWrY — Fine Gael (@FineGael) October 18, 2015 Fine Gael is the largest party in Ireland’s Oireachtas (National Parliament) and they were no doubt hoping to cheer Irish supporters up by highlighting economic success ahead of what would hopefully be Irish sporting success It probably didn’t quite get the response it hoped for as a deluge of angry Irish fans jumped into the conversation mock the tweet. @FineGael FACT: If the Rugby World Cup were based on Government Debt per Person, Ireland would win hands down. — Richard Keogh (@GreySombrero) October 18, 2015 @FineGael stop ruining this for everyone. — Gavin Sweeney (@Gavin_Pauls) October 18, 2015 @FineGael We're also top of the RWC table (and second in the West) in income inequality thanks to your policies. #IREvARG — Mike McGrath-Bryan (@mike_mcgb) October 18, 2015 I bet whoever curates the @FineGael account is wishing now they didn't go here #rugby https://t.co/y2th9gnnFF — ann marie part (@PartAnnMarie) October 18, 2015 @FineGael if the Rugby World Cup was based on Emigration since 2008, Ireland would win hands down — The Dublin Cynic (@thedublincynic) October 18, 2015 But for those who have heard the music of Garth Brooks, maybe this Tweet was even worse. @garthbrooks showing his support for Ireland in Today's big match #IREvARG #RWC15 pic.twitter.com/nHF8ugxxqO — Ryan O Neill (@radioryanoneill) October 18, 2015 Telegraphsportpage Follow @telegraphsport
